    Programmatic Data Retrieval from the WHO

    Eric Persson

    2019-06-29

    who_vignette.Rmd

    Introduction

    The WHO package allows the user to download public health data from the World Health Organization’s Global Health Observatory in a dynamic and reproducible way.

    The package can be installed from either CRAN or Github (development version):

    # From CRAN
install.packages("WHO")

# From Github
library(devtools)
install_github("expersso/WHO")

library(WHO)

    Usage Example

    The get_codes function returns a data frame with series codes and descriptions for all available series:

    library(dplyr)

codes <- get_codes()
glimpse(codes)
    ## Observations: 3,274
## Variables: 3
## $ label   <chr> "MDG_0000000001", "MDG_0000000003", "MDG_0000000005", ...
## $ display <chr> "Infant mortality rate (probability of dying between b...
## $ url     <chr> "http://apps.who.int/gho/indicatorregistry/App_Main/vi...

    (To retrieve additional meta information (e.g. French and Spanish descriptions, category breakdowns of series, etc), use get_codes(extra = TRUE).)

    To find a series of interest, use either View(codes) in Rstudio, or search with regular expressions:

    codes[grepl("[Ll]ife expectancy", codes$display), ]
    ##           label                                          display
## 1 WHOSIS_000001                 Life expectancy at birth (years)
## 2 WHOSIS_000002  Healthy life expectancy (HALE) at birth (years)
## 3 WHOSIS_000015                Life expectancy at age 60 (years)
## 4 WHOSIS_000007 Healthy life expectancy (HALE) at age 60 (years)
##                                                                               url
## 1   http://apps.who.int/gho/indicatorregistry/App_Main/view_indicator.aspx?iid=65
## 2   http://apps.who.int/gho/indicatorregistry/App_Main/view_indicator.aspx?iid=66
## 3 http://apps.who.int/gho/indicatorregistry/App_Main/view_indicator.aspx?iid=2977
## 4   http://apps.who.int/gho/indicatorregistry/App_Main/view_indicator.aspx?iid=66

    Having found the series of interest (in the label column), we can easily retrieve the data and, for example, make a chart:

    library(ggplot2)

df <- get_data("WHOSIS_000001")

head(df)
    ## # A tibble: 6 x 7
##   country sex       region gho                      year publishstate value
##   <chr>   <chr>     <chr>  <chr>                   <dbl> <chr>        <dbl>
## 1 Rwanda  Male      Africa Life expectancy at bir~  2001 Published     43.5
## 2 Rwanda  Female    Africa Life expectancy at bir~  2001 Published     49.5
## 3 Rwanda  Both sex~ Africa Life expectancy at bir~  2003 Published     50.2
## 4 Rwanda  Male      Africa Life expectancy at bir~  2004 Published     49  
## 5 Rwanda  Both sex~ Africa Life expectancy at bir~  2006 Published     56.7
## 6 Rwanda  Male      Africa Life expectancy at bir~  2007 Published     55.2
    df %>% 
  filter(sex == "Both sexes") %>% 
  group_by(region, year) %>%
  summarise(value = mean(value)) %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = year, y = value, color = region, linetype = region)) +
  geom_line(size = 1) +
  theme_light(9) +
  labs(x = NULL, y = "Life expectancy at birth (years)\n", 
       linetype = NULL, color = NULL,
       title = "Evolution of life expectancy (by region)\n")
